text:
0 COMMENTS FIFA banned Marco Polo Del Nero, president of Brazilian Soccer Confederation, for life; he's seen here in 2015 in Rio de Janeiro. Photo: Reuters
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
FIFA banned for life Brazil’s soccer chief following a corruption investigation, but his lawyers said there was no evidence to support the ban. (AFP, AP)
French billionaire Vincent Bollore was formally charged as part of a probe concerning alleged Africa bribery. A spokesman confirmed Mr. Bollore was charged and said he will respond. The case is putting French antibribery enforcement on the map. (AFP, OCCRP, Quint)
Taiwan’s highest court upheld the bribery sentence on a former judge. (TT)
Cybercrime:
Eugene Kaspersky slammed Twitter for banning his cybersecurity firm’s advertisements. (Computing)
Money Laundering:
Peru’s highest court ordered the release of a former president and his wife being held pending trial. (Bloomberg)
Latvia’s parliament voted to use laws aimed at tackling money laundering to force banks to scale back bank ties to shell companies. (Reuters)
China’s central bank said it will crack down on money laundering and financial crimes. (Reuters)
U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May faces a parliamentary move to force the Crown Territories to reveal corrupt oligarchs registering companies. (Times)
Former Brazil Finance Minister Antonio Palocci struck a plea deal ; he’s already serving 12 years for money laundering. (Reuters)
The American Bar Association faces internal disagreement over whether to support anti-money laundering reforms. (Politico)
Ireland’s cabinet approved anti-money laundering rules to bring it in line with EU regulations. (ILN)
A former U.S. nuclear procurement officer was sentenced for fraud and money laundering. (release)
Indian authorities continue to pursue money-laundering cases. (Express)
Sanctions:
Republican fundraiser Elliot Broidy offered a Russian gas company a plan to help it get off the U.S. sanctions list–for $26 million. Mr. Broidy said the deal never was concluded. (Intercept)
Preserving the Iran nuclear deal is a top priority for Germany. U.S. negotiators say they want to add to the agreement . Moscow sees no room for additions. (Atlantic, Reuters, NPR, AC, AM, AC, Reuters)
China opposes imposing domestic laws on foreigners, an official said in response to a question about allegations Huawei violated U.S. sanctions. (Reuters, SCMP)
A suspected Colombian drug kingpin under U.S. sanctions was extradited . (release)
Terrorism Finance:
French prosecutors identified hundreds of Islamic State donors. (AFP)
Transparency:
Spanish authorities acknowledged , after earlier denials, they arrested a married couple with links to late Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez over suspected corruption in their home country revealed through the Panama Papers. The couple’s lawyer said the allegations comprise a political prosecution. (AP)
Whistleblowers:
The Cambridge Analytica whistleblower is still talking . (Splinter, DB, Vice)
General Anti-Corruption:
Maltese taxpayers are losing out on billions in a gas deal with Azerbaijan, documents show. A Maltese bank remains open despite government concerns about Azerbaijani clients. (OCCRP, Reuters)
U.S. environmental chief Scott Pruitt called lies the ethics scandals plaguing him . (Reuters, Politico, BuzzFeed)
Romania’s top politician skipped a hearing on corruption charges, visiting Israel. (JP, ToI)
China made new allegations of corruption against fugitive billionaire Guo Wengui; he denies wrongdoing. Chinese companies are seen as less corrupt amid Xi Jinping’s antigraft drive . (Nikkei, SCMP, Bloomberg)
Taiwan’s president hopes to improve the climate for foreign investment through antigraft enforcement. (TN)
The G-7 called for Ukraine to improve its anticorruption mechanisms. (Interfax)
Japan’s business community likes the premier despite his cronyism scandal. (Reuters)
Indigenous communities in Kenya hope new rules will fight corruption. (OCCRP)
The DEA is investigating a former agent linked to Colombian drug traffickers; he couldn’t be reached. (TTW)
The U.S. Senate admonished Sen. Robert Menendez (D., N.J.) for taking gifts from a donor. Mr. Menendez wonders if his re-election effort will be targeted by Russia. (Politico, NYT, AP)
U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions wouldn’t say whether he was recused from the probe of Michael Cohen, personal lawyer for President Donald Trump. (Politico, Bloomberg, Reuters, NYT)
The U.S. special counsel’s probe received bipartisan backing from a Senate panel that approved a bill protecting him and the investigation. (HuffPost, Slate, Bloomberg, Politico, NPR)
Local analysis of the EY corruption survey is available from the U.K. , Poland and India . (Economia, BNE, TN)
